instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
Hi guys , this is a MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.  See attached photo. There was once F7700 where the hole is now. Looking at the Boardview it would need around 19 jumper wires. Would anyone attempt this ? if so do you have any advice?

Thanks - Bob

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
19 wires for?
Just need to run a wire from any <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> point to F7700.
Solder new fuse in one point only: or bypass it directly.

Be aware on the opposite side, may need to rebuild some traces.
Not necessary if thunderbolt is not used.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Super, there is no damage on the opposite side. It also seems <RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR> is missing, you can see its gone in the photo.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR> was never soldered!
There is direct trace between its pads...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi 2informaticos, I have replaced F7700 by soldering pin 2 to its pad and then running a wire to pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C3080</CAPACITOR>. I have a short on <CAPACITOR>C7712</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7713</CAPACITOR>. I have a Flir One Pro LT and the attached shows the fuse and <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> glowing. Looking around the area <CAPACITOR>C7799</CAPACITOR> was discoloured so I have replaced it. I have removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> and still get the short. the amperage is 0.24A and I now get a green light on the charger which I never got prior. I replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. Any ideas ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
Where exactly do you note the short?
Power rail name, please.
Did you clean internal edge of the hole?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi, I have an OL on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and I cleaned the edge of the hole with Isopropyl alcohol.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
Then where is the short???
Before, or after <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi, I have removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, F7700 and <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR> and I still see the exact same hotspot. I think the issue is that the short is on the board now, I think. I think this because if I drop alcohol over the area it evaporates very quickly in the hole and I can even see the alcohol sizzling. Is there anything that can be done about this ? obviously I am not at your level or I would not be asking so if you can think of anything else please say as I may not have thought of it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Polish the hole edge until short is gone.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi thanks for coming back to me. I have removed F7700 and re run the wire from the pad where pin 2 of F7700 should go to pin 2 of F7140 and the short has gone. I am getting 225mv on pin 2 of F7140 now. Checking the thermal camera the temprate has gone down and I dont see the same alcohol evaporating of the area with the hold. See image 1. However I have now got a hot spot around <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, image2. Can you also advise what to use to polish , I have never done this before.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
Please check in diode mode on power rails and find the short.
If a component heats, should have bad reading on output pin...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Thanks I will do this, can you tell me how you would polish the burn hole? I have never needed to do this before.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi, I know for sure that the short is in the hole, I have scraped and tried to "polish" with a black stick. Can anyone offer any tips of removing shorts like this?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: I have managed to , I think, remove the short. Like I said I have soldered a wire to pad 2 of F7700 and run the wire to pin 1 of F7140. F7140 is reaching 140 degrees now so I still have an issue but its moved. Any ideas or pointers would be great, is running the wire between these points correct? looking at the board view it seemed to be.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, with the wire soldered between both fuses.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: With multimeter in diode mode , red probe on ground black probe on pin 2 of F7140 I get 0.002

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
That is less than 5 ohm, still short; 2-3 ohm in fact.
I hope you've removed power, before measuring in diode mode.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Hi , so yes I did remove the power. I know you are mega busy but is there anything that you can add that might help me here ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message:
No other way than eliminate the short.
If you are sure the short is inside board (between copper layers), is not easy at all.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Logicboard with hole
threads.message: Ok. Thank you for the help.
